txt: shoutout to snapchat for finally allowing its users to change their usernames - 'asianp3rsuasi0n' was about to haunt me to the afterlife

The model minority myth is essentially this notion that Asians are innately high achieving, despite being a minority. It is rooted in stereotypes, and can be confusing because how can 'positive' stereotypes (i.e., being high achieving), be bad?

Historical events such as Chinese immigrants working on the nation's first railroads, and the Chinese Exclusion Act were very briefly covered when I studied U.S. history in high school, but never on a much deeper level than the fact that they happened. I even had a classmate tell me once that 'it was ok' because 'Asians are so successful now'.

Whew there's a lot to unpack here. The model minority myth perpetuates the idea that there is a certain way people of color are meant to 'succeed'. It is used to drive a wedge between minority groups, it disregards diversity amongst Asians, and it erases our history. There's a lot more to say on this, and this essay isn't about the model minority myth, but feel free to read more about it at https://www.learningforjustice.org/magazine/what-is-the-model-minority-myth
